The Committee on Appropriations Resolution amends Section 302(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Committee on Appropriations of each House to report an original joint resolution on appropriations allocations after consulting with the other House. This joint resolution includes subdivisions among subcommittees for budget outlays and new budget authority, as well as a breakdown of controllable amounts. The joint resolution reported by the Committee on Appropriations includes subdivisions among subcommittees for budget outlays and new budget authority, as well as a breakdown of controllable amounts. Debate in the Senate on the joint resolution is limited to 20 hours, and the Committee on Appropriations manages the resolution. The allocations of the Committees on Appropriations do not take effect until the joint resolution is enacted into law. The joint resolution reported by the Committee on Appropriations includes subdivisions among subcommittees for budget outlays and new budget authority. Each committee, except the Committees on Appropriations, must further subdivide their allocations and report to their respective House promptly. The allocations of the Committees on Appropriations do not take effect until the joint resolution is enacted into law. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require committees to make allocations in accordance with guidelines. Any alterations to allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations must be approved. Committees can report alterations to allocations after reporting initial allocations, which must align with previous House actions. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO APPROPRIATIONS BILL. Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to allow floor amendments to appropriations bills that reduce budget authority and relevant subcommittee allocations, as well as discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year covered by the bill and the following four fiscal years. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to allow floor amendments to appropriations bills that reduce budget authority, subcommittee allocations, and discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year covered by the bill and the following four fiscal years. Conference reports on appropriations bills must not contain provisions that reduce allocations and spending less than what was passed by the Senate or House of Representatives. SEC. 4. SECTION 602(b) ALLOCATIONS. The Committee on Appropriations of each House shall make allocations under subsection (a)(1)(A) or (a)(2) in accordance with section 302(b)(1).
